Described Disease.Described Disease: Parkinson's disease (PD) / Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)

Material used.Description: Human SNCA cDNA was cloned into the NdeI and HindIII restriction sites of the bacterial expression vector pRK172. The cDNAs coding for the mutant SNCA proteins E46A, E46K, E83A, and E83K were engineered by creating the corresponding nucleotide substitutions in the wild-type cDNA.

Readout description.Result Description: The E46K mutation increased the propensity of SNCA to fibrillize compared with the WT protein.
The A53T mutation increased the propensity of SNCA to fibrillize to a greater extent than the E46K mutation.
The E46A mutation increased the propensity to polymerize, but this substitution resulted in two types of mature fibrils.
The E83A mutation increased the ability of SNCA to polymerize, but the resulting filaments showed reduced characteristics of true amyloid.
The E83K mutation increased the ability of SNCA to polymerize, but the resulting filaments showed reduced characteristics of true amyloid.

Biological replicates.Description: All experiments were conducted multiple times.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type SNCA protein was used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Buffer without protein was used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Densitometry of Coomassie Blue-stained SDS-polyacrylamide gels or 125I quantitative Western blotting analysis.

Material used.Description: Human SNCA cDNA was cloned into the NdeI and HindIII restriction sites of the bacterial expression vector pRK172. The cDNAs coding for the mutant SNCA proteins E46A, E46K, E83A, and E83K were engineered by creating the corresponding nucleotide substitutions in the wild-type cDNA.

Readout description.Result Description: The E46K mutant polymerized more readily than the WT protein.
The A53T mutation increased the propensity of SNCA to fibrillize to a greater extent than the E46K mutation.
The E46A mutation increased the propensity to polymerize, but this substitution resulted in two types of mature fibrils.
The E83A mutation increased the ability of SNCA to polymerize, but the resulting filaments showed reduced characteristics of true amyloid.
The E83K mutation increased the ability of SNCA to polymerize, but the resulting filaments showed reduced characteristics of true amyloid.

Biological replicates.Description: All experiments were conducted multiple times.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type SNCA protein was used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Buffer without protein was used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Fluorescence measurement with a SpectraMax Gemini fluorometer and SoftMax Pro 4.0 software.

Material used.Description: Human SNCA cDNA was cloned into the NdeI and HindIII restriction sites of the bacterial expression vector pRK172. The cDNAs coding for the mutant SNCA proteins E46A, E46K, E83A, and E83K were engineered by creating the corresponding nucleotide substitutions in the wild-type cDNA.

Readout description.Result Description: The E46K mutation converted from random coil conformation to β-sheet more readily than the WT protein.
The A53T mutation increased the propensity of SNCA to fibrillize to a greater extent than the E46K mutation.
The E46A mutation increased the propensity to polymerize, but this substitution resulted in two types of mature fibrils.
The E83A mutation increased the ability of SNCA to polymerize, but the resulting filaments showed reduced characteristics of true amyloid.
The E83K mutation increased the ability of SNCA to polymerize, but the resulting filaments showed reduced characteristics of true amyloid.

Biological replicates.Description: All experiments were conducted multiple times.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type SNCA protein was used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Buffer without protein was used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: CD spectra were recorded using an Aviv model 202 spectrophotometer.

The cDNAs coding for the mutant SNCA proteins E46A, E46K, E83A, and E83K were engineered by creating the corresponding nucleotide substitutions in the wild-type cDNA.

Readout description.Result Description: The E46K mutation converted from random coil conformation to β-sheet more readily than the WT protein.
The A53T mutation increased the propensity of SNCA to fibrillize to a greater extent than the E46K mutation.
The E46A mutation increased the propensity to polymerize, but this substitution resulted in two types of mature fibrils.
The E83A mutation increased the ability of SNCA to polymerize, but the resulting filaments showed reduced characteristics of true amyloid.
The E83K mutation increased the ability of SNCA to polymerize, but the resulting filaments showed reduced characteristics of true amyloid.

Biological replicates.Description: All experiments were conducted multiple times.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type SNCA protein was used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Buffer without protein was used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: ATR-FTIR spectra were collected on a Digilab FTS-60A equipped with a wide band MCT detector.

Material used.Description: Human SNCA cDNA was cloned into the NdeI and HindIII restriction sites of the bacterial expression vector pRK172. The cDNAs coding for the mutant SNCA proteins E46A, E46K, E83A, and E83K were engineered by creating the corresponding nucleotide substitutions in the wild-type cDNA.

Readout description.Result Description: The E46K mutant protein had a tendency to form compact bundles of fibrils.
The A53T mutation increased the propensity of SNCA to fibrillize to a greater extent than the E46K mutation.
The E46A mutation increased the propensity to polymerize, but this substitution resulted in two types of mature fibrils.
The E83A mutation increased the ability of SNCA to polymerize, but the resulting filaments showed reduced characteristics of true amyloid.
The E83K mutation increased the ability of SNCA to polymerize, but the resulting filaments showed reduced characteristics of true amyloid.

Biological replicates.Description: All experiments were conducted multiple times.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type SNCA protein was used as a positive control.

Basic negative control.Description: Buffer without protein was used as a negative control.

Statistical analysis method.Statistical analysis method: Images were captured with a Hamamatsu digital camera using AMT software.
